sources: Lattice Training — warmup and conditioning protocols
Bechtel climbstrong.com — general athleticism for climbers

vocabulary_gap_flags.issue: 'carry' pattern does not describe cardio/locomotion exercises. Both jump_rope and bear_crawl are locomotion/conditioning patterns, not carries.
vocabulary_gap_flags.recommendation: Add 'locomotion' pattern to vocabulary_v1.md and update these two exercises. Alternatively add 'cardio' as a separate pattern. ACTION REQUIRED in vocabulary_v1.md before applying to engine.

updates_complementary.description: Chest-to-wall handstand hold — hands 15-20 cm from wall, belly facing wall, walk feet up and establish vertical alignment. Foundational static handstand skill. Develops shoulder overhead stability, wrist strength, and body tension. Prerequisite for all other handstand work.
cues: Face wall, hands 15-20 cm from baseboard — palms flat, fingers spread
Walk feet up the wall and step hands closer until body is vertical
Active shoulders: push floor away aggressively — do not collapse into shoulders
Squeeze glutes and engage core to prevent lower back arch
Eyes look at the floor between hands — do not look at the wall
20s hold is the entry target — build to 60s before progressing

updates_complementary.description: Walking feet up the wall from push-up position to fully vertical handstand, then walking back down. Trains the handstand entry, overhead shoulder stability, and proprioception under load. A safer and more controllable handstand entry than kicking up from the floor. Also a useful shoulder strength exercise in its own right.
cues: Start in push-up position feet close to wall
Walk feet up the wall and hands progressively closer to wall simultaneously
Aim to reach vertical with hands close to wall (10-15 cm)
Pause at the top for 2-3 seconds before walking back down with control
Speed is the enemy: slow, controlled movements improve stability and strength
2 reps = 1 up and 1 down controlled

updates_complementary.description: In chest-to-wall handstand: briefly lift one hand and tap the opposite shoulder, then return and alternate. Unilateral loading of each shoulder in the overhead position. Develops the lateral stability and wrist control needed for freestanding balance. 4 reps = 2 per side.
cues: Only attempt once wall hold is stable for 20+ seconds
Shift weight entirely to one hand before lifting the other
Keep the tap quick: 1 second off the floor maximum
Core and glutes must remain tight — no hip sag during the tap
If hips rotate during taps, reduce rep count and focus on core tension first

updates_complementary.description: 10-minute dedicated freestanding handstand practice session — kicking up, finding balance, and accumulating freestanding time. Long-term skill development, not a strength set. Balance work adapts slowly; consistent daily or every-other-day practice with low fatigue is superior to infrequent high-volume sessions.
cues: Kick-up: one foot steps close to hands, powerful swing of back leg overhead
Balanced position: slight hollow body (not arched), active shoulders, eyes on floor
Use a wall as spotter but attempt to find the balance point independently
Pirouetting out of failed attempts is safer than crashing — learn cartwheel bail
Track freestanding seconds per session — improvement is measured in seconds, not minutes

updates_complementary.description: Strict wall handstand push-up. From chest-to-wall handstand: lower crown of head toward floor, pause, press back to full lockout. Targets anterior deltoid, triceps, and upper trapezius under full bodyweight overhead load. Demanding exercise — requires solid 30s+ wall hold and consistent full-extension overhead pressing strength as prerequisite.
cues: Only attempt if freestanding handstand or 30s+ wall hold is established
Lower slowly: 3-second controlled eccentric to head barely touching floor
Press to complete lockout — no partial reps
If elbow flare occurs: keep elbows slightly inside the wrist line (not wide flare)
Stop at the first rep where lockout is incomplete — do not grind through form breakdown
Pike push-up is the direct regression if reps are not achievable

updates_conditioning.description: Jump rope (skipping) cardio conditioning — continuous or interval skipping for pulse raise and cardiovascular warm-up. One of the highest-efficiency low-skill cardio tools: requires minimal equipment, zero gym footprint, and raises heart rate rapidly. Standard tool in climbing gym warm-ups. NOTE: pattern field flagged as vocabulary gap ('carry' is incorrect — update vocab to 'locomotion' first).
cues: Basic bounce: both feet together, minimal wrist movement, rope turns from wrists not elbows
Aim for consistent 70-80 RPM rhythm — not maximum speed
Land on balls of feet, soft knees — never flat-footed
5 min continuous is the baseline. If tripping frequently, shorten to 2×2 min with 1 min rest
No jump rope? Simulate: same footwork and arm motion without rope — nearly equal HR benefit

updates_conditioning.description: Turkish get-up (TGU) — full floor-to-standing sequence while holding a weight overhead in one arm. Trains integrated shoulder stability, hip mobility, and core rotation through the largest range of motion of any single exercise. Bechtel and Hörst both recommend TGU for climbing-specific general athleticism and shoulder resilience. 2 reps per side = very high quality work volume.
cues: Start lying, arm vertical with weight directly above shoulder, eyes on the weight throughout
Sequence: roll to elbow → press to hand → bridge hips up → sweep back knee → kneeling → stand
Reverse the sequence to lower — every step is controlled
Weight is a kettlebell ideally, but a dumbbell or even a shoe works to learn
2 reps/side at quality > 5 reps/side rushed. Never sacrifice the eye-on-weight rule
Beginners: learn with no weight first, then a shoe, then a light kettlebell

updates_conditioning.description: Farmer's carry — walking with heavy loads held at sides. Trains grip endurance, anti-lateral-flexion core stability, and loaded walking mechanics. Carries are recommended in Hörst and Bechtel programming as general conditioning that builds real-world climbing grip endurance and trunk stability without specific climbing movements.
cues: Weight in each hand — kettlebells, dumbbells, or loaded buckets all work
Stand tall: shoulders retracted and depressed, chest up, core braced
Steps should be controlled — not waddling or leaning to either side
30s carry at chosen weight, rest 60s, repeat 3 times
Load: should feel heavy in grip by 20s. If grip is not the limiter, weight is too light
Single-arm variation: one side at a time trains anti-lateral-flexion more specifically

updates_conditioning.description: Bear crawl — quadruped locomotion with knees hovering 5 cm off floor. Trains anterior core stability, contralateral coordination, and shoulder stability through a full locomotion pattern. Used in Bechtel general conditioning circuits and Uphill Athlete climbing programs. NOTE: pattern field flagged as vocabulary gap ('carry' is incorrect — update vocab to 'locomotion' first).
cues: Start on all-fours, knees hovering 5 cm off floor — do not let knees touch
Move right hand and left foot simultaneously, then left hand and right foot
Hips stay level — avoid rocking side to side
Forward AND backward: bear crawl forward 10m, then back 10m = 1 set
Slow is harder and more useful: 2-second steps develop more stability than rushing
Harder variant: backwards bear crawl, or with weight vest

updates_mobility.description: Thoracic spine and shoulder mobility flow — combining thoracic CARs (controlled articular rotations), cat-cow, thread-the-needle, and open-book rotations. Targets the thoracic extension and rotation deficit common in climbers from sustained forward-flexed postures on overhanging walls. 5 minutes pre-session for optimal shoulder range.
cues: Cat-cow: 10 slow cycles — fully exhale at the top of cat, fully inhale at cow
Thread-the-needle: from all-fours, slide one arm under body and rotate, hold 5s each side × 5
Open-book: side-lying, top arm sweeps open while lower arm stays, eyes follow the hand
T-spine CARs: seated on heels, hands behind head, rotate thorax maximally — 5 each direction
Do not force range: the goal is controlled quality rotation, not maximum stretch
